questionText: What is the primary purpose of a stock market?
options: To provide a platform for buying and selling company ownership shares
To regulate interest rates for banks
To print money for the government
To provide loans to small businesses
Putting all your money in one stock
Spreading investments across different assets to reduce risk
Investing only in technology companies
Buying stocks on margin

questionText: In an epic battle between Duke Nukem and the Doom Slayer, who would emerge victorious and why?
options: Duke Nukem wins because he has better one-liners and a cooler attitude
The Doom Slayer wins because he can RIP AND TEAR through demons with unstoppable fury, making him the ultimate demon-slaying machine
It's a tie because both are equally powerful
Neither wins because they're both fictional characters
A fee charged by brokers
A portion of a company's profits paid to shareholders
The initial price of a stock
A type of bond
A market where stock prices are rising
A market where stock prices are falling or expected to fall
A market that trades only animal-related stocks
A market open only during bear season
Interest calculated only on the principal amount
Interest calculated on both the principal and previously earned interest
A type of loan interest
Interest that compounds daily

questionText: What is the difference between a stock and a bond?
options: Stocks represent ownership, bonds represent debt
Bonds represent ownership, stocks represent debt
There is no difference
Stocks are riskier than bonds, but bonds pay more
A market where prices are falling
A market where prices are rising or expected to rise
A market that trades cattle futures
A market that only operates in the morning
A single stock
A collection of stocks or bonds that trades like a stock
A type of savings account
A government bond

questionText: What is the 'Rule of 72' used for?
options: Calculating stock prices
Estimating how long it takes for an investment to double
Determining bond yields
Calculating tax rates
A type of savings account
A retirement savings plan sponsored by an employer
A type of insurance policy
A government assistance program
How much water a company uses
How easily an asset can be converted to cash
The amount of debt a company has
The profit margin of a company
When prices decrease over time
When the general price level of goods and services increases over time
When the stock market crashes
When interest rates go up
A single stock investment
A pool of money from many investors used to buy a diversified portfolio
A type of bank account
A government bond

questionText: What does 'P/E ratio' stand for and what does it measure?
options: Price/Earnings ratio - measures how expensive a stock is relative to its earnings
Profit/Expense ratio - measures company profitability
Purchase/Equity ratio - measures stock ownership
Principal/Equity ratio - measures debt levels
Investing a fixed amount regularly regardless of price
Buying stocks only when prices are low
Selling stocks when prices are high
Investing all money at once

questionText: What is a market cap (market capitalization)?
options: The total value of all a company's outstanding shares
The price of a single share
The company's annual revenue
The company's total debt

questionText: What is the difference between a Roth IRA and a Traditional IRA?
options: Roth IRA contributions are tax-deductible, Traditional IRA withdrawals are tax-free
Roth IRA contributions are taxed now, withdrawals are tax-free; Traditional IRA contributions are tax-deductible, withdrawals are taxed
There is no difference
Roth IRA is for stocks, Traditional IRA is for bonds
An order to buy a stock at a specific price
An order to sell a stock if it falls to a specific price
An order to hold a stock indefinitely
An order to transfer stocks between accounts
A single company's stock
A stock market index tracking 500 large U.S. companies
A type of bond
A government agency
A stock that pays high dividends
A large, well-established, financially stable company
A new startup company
A stock that trades for less than $1
Selling a stock you own
Borrowing and selling a stock with the hope of buying it back cheaper
Selling stocks quickly
Selling stocks at a loss
A fund that tries to beat the market
A fund that tracks a specific market index
A fund that invests in only one company
A fund that only invests in bonds
A regular brokerage account
An account that allows borrowing money to buy securities
A savings account with high interest
A retirement account

questionText: What is the difference between active and passive investing?
options: Active investing tries to beat the market, passive investing tracks market indexes
Passive investing tries to beat the market, active investing tracks indexes
There is no difference
Active investing is riskier, passive is safer
The total amount of dividends paid
The annual dividend payment divided by the stock price, expressed as a percentage
The number of times dividends are paid per year
The growth rate of dividends
How much money you have
How you divide investments among different asset categories
The total value of your portfolio
The number of stocks you own
When a company divides existing shares into multiple shares
When a company goes bankrupt
When two companies merge
When a stock price doubles

questionText: What is the difference between a growth stock and a value stock?
options: Growth stocks are expected to grow faster, value stocks are undervalued relative to fundamentals
Value stocks grow faster, growth stocks are undervalued
There is no difference
Growth stocks pay dividends, value stocks don't
Buying more of the same stocks
Adjusting asset allocation back to target percentages
Selling all stocks
Moving money to a savings account
